Drug Reactions (e.g., to sulfa drugs, anticonvulsants, NSAIDs)
Drug reactions with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Mononucleosis (infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems in the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including arthritis, nephritis, psychosis, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: Although RA is primarily known for causing joint inflammation and arthropathy, it can also lead to pericardial effusions and, in rare cases, nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease is characterized by features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can present with synovitis, nephritis, arthropathy, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the salivary and lacrimal glands, Sjogren's syndrome can also cause joint problems (arthropathy), nephritis, and has been associated with nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Schizophrenia
diagnoses.rationale: Schizophrenia can present with psychosis and, though less commonly, has been associated with autoimmune responses that might indirectly cause symptoms like pericardial effusion through comorbid conditions.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This form of arthritis occurs in some individuals with psoriasis and can present with synovitis and arthropathy, and less commonly nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the spine and the sacroiliac joint but can have manifestations outside of the musculoskeletal system including uveitis and rarely pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitis, such as in Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, can cause kidney problems (nephritis), joint pains, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: In its late stages, Lyme disease can cause arthritis (Lyme arthritis), nephritis, neurological disorders (which can include psychosis), and in rare cases, pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting the heart valves, infective endocarditis can lead to systemic symptoms such as arthritis, glomerulonephritis (a type of nephritis), and in rare cases, embolic phenomena causing psychosis.

diagnoses: Rickettsial Diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)
Vasculitis (e.g., Henoch-Schönlein purpura, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Schizophrenia (in rare cases with severe systemic disease)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include delayed puberty, constipation, and difficulty focusing vision. Elevated immunoglobulins could be seen in autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto's disease).

diagnoses.name: Hyperimmunoglobulin E Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare immunodeficiency disorder characterized by high levels of serum immunoglobulin E (IgE). Symptoms can include recurrent infections leading to fever (hyperthermia) and other nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. It can cause constipation and delay puberty. Though not typical, it can be associated with elevated immunoglobulins in the context of autoimmune response.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly. Symptoms might include increased infections (leading to hyperthermia) and elevated levels of immunoglobulins as a compensatory mechanism.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type I (MEN1)
diagnoses.description: A rare hereditary condition predisposing individuals to develop tumors of the endocrine glands. It could indirectly cause a variety of symptoms including those listed, through endocrine gland dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the immune system's ability to fight certain infections. It is associated with high levels of immunoglobulins and can lead to various symptoms, including fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in various organs, which can cause a wide range of symptoms including visual disturbances and elevated immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that can produce lesions in various organs including the bone, skin, and pituitary gland, potentially leading to delayed puberty and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Pituitary Adenoma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the pituitary gland that can affect hormonal release, potentially causing delayed puberty and other hormonal imbalances that might indirectly lead to the listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism), but in unusual cases, might present atypically and affect multiple body systems, leading to a broad range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark of diabetes. In long-standing cases, diabetes can lead to complications including vision difficulties, tinnitus, and hearing loss through mechanisms like microvascular damage.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic high blood pressure can lead to target organ damage affecting the eyes (leading to difficulty focusing vision) and ears (contributing to tinnitus and hearing loss). Hypertension can coexist with diabetes, potentially exacerbating hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition can lead to hypertension and hyperglycemia as part of its symptomatology. It can also cause fluid retention and changes in metabolism that might indirectly contribute to symptoms like tinnitus and difficulties with vision.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune diseases, like lupus, can cause a wide array of symptoms including hypersensitivity reactions. They can also contribute to conditions like diabetes and hypertension which in turn can lead to vision and hearing issues.

diagnoses.name: Meniere’s Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This disease primarily affects the inner ear, leading to tinnitus, hearing loss, and bouts of vertigo. Though it does not directly cause hyperglycemia, the stress of dealing with a chronic condition could indirectly affect blood sugar levels.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.reasoning: This benign tumor of the cranial nerve can lead to hearing loss and tinnitus. It doesn't typically cause hyperglycemia but could indirectly contribute to difficulties focusing vision due to impact on the brain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: MS can lead to optic neuritis, causing difficulties with vision. It may also impact the central nervous system in a way that leads to auditory problems like tinnitus and hearing loss, though hyperglycemia would be unrelated.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can indirectly affect hearing and vision, in addition to influencing glucose metabolism and possibly leading to hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This syndrome includes a slew of symptoms including hyperglycemia. The syndrome's association with obesity and hypertension can also indirectly affect vision and hearing.

diagnoses.name: Age-related Macular Degeneration
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily associated with vision loss and difficulty focusing vision, in the context of a patient with multiple symptoms like hyperglycemia, it could co-occur with conditions like diabetes that also cause tinnitus and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: Also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome, it temporarily weakens the myocardium due to severe emotional or physical stress.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear, potentially contributing to the development of conditions like Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition where chronic pain, such as back pain, leads to significant psychological and emotional distress, potentially worsening conditions like anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Presyncope
diagnoses.description: A state of lightheadedness, muscular weakness, and feeling faint without the actual loss of consciousness, which can be associated with cardiovascular conditions.

diagnoses.name: Dyshidrotic Eczema
diagnoses.description: A skin condition characterized by small blisters on the hands or feet, often linked to stress, which might relate to anxiety disorders.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental disorder characterized by a pervasive and persistent low mood that is accompanied by low self-esteem and by a loss of interest or pleasure in normally enjoyable activities, which can have a complex relationship with chronic pain and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues, which may overlap with chronic back pain and anxiety symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by excessive, uncontrollable, and often irrational worry about everyday things that is disproportionate to the actual source of worry.

diagnoses.name: Panic Disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by recurring unexpected panic attacks. Panic attacks are sudden periods of intense fear that may include palpitations, sweating, or feelings of doom, potentially overlapping with symptoms of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
diagnoses.description: A psychiatric disorder that may occur in people who have experienced or witnessed a traumatic event, often manifesting symptoms such as flashbacks, nightmares, severe anxiety, and uncontrollable thoughts about the event, that could trigger or exacerbate conditions like Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus – considering the presence of hyperglycemia.
Chronic Inflammatory Conditions – which may link to recurrent otitis media and possibly contribute to vulvodynia.
Autoimmune Disorders – systemic conditions like Sjogren's syndrome or lupus could tie together diverse symptoms through immune dysregulation.
Fibromyalgia – given the chronic pain (e.g., vulvodynia) and potential inflammatory responses.
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) – could explain hyperglycemia and may have some association with vulvodynia through hormonal imbalances.
Metabolic Syndrome – considering hyperglycemia and potential links to other systemic symptoms.
Chronic Infections – certain chronic infections could potentially explain recurring otitis media and laryngitis.
Benign Vascular Disorders – for the angiomata, especially if they are widespread, indicating a systemic process.
Neurological Conditions – certain conditions could theoretically link nerve dysfunction (vulvodynia) with other symptoms like laryngitis (via vagus nerve involvement).
Endocrine Disorders – aside from diabetes, other glandular issues could be underlying causes for a series of these symptoms.
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark symptom, and mood lability can occur due to fluctuations in blood sugar levels.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by dry eyes and irritated eyes due to its autoimmune nature affecting the exocrine glands.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Coryza (nasal congestion and runny nose), could be a symptom, often accompanied by eye irritation due to allergens.

diagnoses.name: Seasonal Allergies
diagnoses.reasoning: Similar to allergic rhinitis, with symptoms like coryza, irritated eyes, and sometimes mood changes due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Dry Eye Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly addresses the symptoms of dry and irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause mood lability and dry eyes, and sometimes hyperglycemia if associated with insulin resistance.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reasoning: Mood lability is a key symptom, and individuals with depression might experience physical symptoms like dry eyes due to reduced blinking from staring (e.g., at screens).

diagnoses.name: Anxiety
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause mood lability; also, stress hormones may indirectly affect blood sugar levels and eye irritation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that can lead to Sjögren's syndrome, thereby causing dry and irritated eyes.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar Disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: Mood lability is a core symptom, and other symptoms may be present due to lifestyle factors or co-occurring conditions.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder that affects multiple parts of the body, including the blood vessels. It can cause mouth and genital ulcers, eye inflammation, and skin rashes. Lymphadenopathy and vision problems may also occur as part of the disease spectrum.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can include fatigue, lymphadenopathy, skin rashes, and ulcers in the nose or mouth. SLE may also lead to complications involving the nervous system, potentially affecting vision.

diagnoses.name: Crohn’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract. Symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, ulcers, and may involve complications outside the GI tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands. It frequently presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, but can also cause joint pain, skin rashes, and systemic complications such as lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) weakens the immune system by attacking T cells, leading to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). Symptoms of advanced HIV/AIDS include lymphadenopathy, mouth ulcers, and various opportunistic infections that can affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, and in cases of extrapulmonary TB, it can involve the genital tract, mimicking or exacerbating endometriosis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. It can cause a range of symptoms including fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and neurological symptoms which might affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and eye inflammation which can affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body. Symptoms can include conjunctivitis or uveitis, which might affect vision, and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions—Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis—that involve chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, diarrhea, and ulcers, with potential for extraintestinal manifestations.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pelvic Pain
diagnoses.description: Chronic pain in the pelvic region, a common manifestation of endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, influenced by endometriosis when structures are involved.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and sometimes pelvic pain, linked with endometriosis and UTIs.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder affecting the large intestine, often associated with endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormones, possibly linked to difficulty concentrating and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar, potentially leading to increased susceptibility to infections and contributing to xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition, often associated with difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as lupus or Sjögren's syndrome that cause the immune system to mistakenly attack healthy cells, possibly explaining increased susceptibility to infections and symptoms like xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Atrophic Vaginitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the vagina due to thinning and shrinking of the tissues, often associated with xerosis and could be compounded by endometriosis treatment effects.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can contribute to difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to increased levels of white blood cells, including basophils, and cause symptoms like fatigue and weight loss. Polycythemia can be a symptom due to increased red blood cell production.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. This can lead to thickened blood and increased basophil counts. Symptoms can include headache, dizziness, and problems caused by increased blood volume and viscosity.

diagnoses.name: Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts your body's normal production of blood cells, leading to scarring in the bone marrow. This condition can cause basophilia and polycythemia in its early stages. It can also lead to anemia and fatigue as it progresses.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where mast cells accumulate in the body's tissues, affecting various organs including the GI tract, skin, and bone marrow. It can cause an increase in basophils. Symptoms range from skin lesions, abdominal discomfort to anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It is not directly associated with basophilia or polycythemia but can lead to menstrual irregularities and may contribute to miscarriages and symptoms such as fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: This is a form of myelofibrosis and is similar in its effects and symptoms but is specified as a primary condition rather than secondary to other conditions. It too can present with basophilia and polycythemia alongside a host of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by the overproduction of platelets by the bone marrow. It can lead to blood clots forming unexpectedly. While not directly linked to basophilia, sufferers might incidentally present with an elevated basophil count.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Covering a range of issues related to improper functioning of the thyroid gland, such conditions can have wide-ranging effects on the body, including impacts on the menstrual cycle that might contribute to miscarriages and could, in some cases, relate to altered blood counts.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as autoimmune diseases (like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis) could potentially lead to varied blood abnormalities including basophilia as part of the body's response to chronic inflammation. These conditions can have wide-reaching impacts including on reproductive health.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Autoimmune disorders, such as Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), can indirectly affect blood counts and reproductive health leading to symptoms like miscarriages and possibly endometriosis due to inflammatory processes that affect various organs and tissues.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with possible vasculitis
Urinary tract infection (in the context of incontinence)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a wide range of potential symptoms, including vision problems, muscle weakness, and coordination issues.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing brain tissue to be deprived of oxygen and nutrients, leading to the death of brain cells.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Glaucoma
diagnoses.description: A group of eye conditions that can cause blindness by damage to the optic nerve, often associated with increased pressure in the eye.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a reduction in vision, pain with eye movement, and sometimes, symptoms like photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord. It can cause severe headaches, fever, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, specifically the temporal arteries, that can cause headache, scalp tenderness, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain, often signaled by a sudden, severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: A series of relatively short but extremely painful headaches every day for weeks or months at a time.

diagnoses: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease)
Schizophrenia (considering the symptom of psychosis separately if not explained by a connective tissue disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
